text: this simple history episode is brought
to you by world of warships The Young
Pioneers 1922 to 1991 the Soviet Union
in 1922 the Soviets replaced the
pre-revolutionary Scout organizations
that existed and had originated from the
United States with his own version that
followed the communist ideology much how
the hitler youth followed Nazi ideals
the Soviets realized how the Scout
movements could effectively unite and
educate children so on May 19 1922 the
Vladimir Lenin all-union pioneer
organization or in short the Young
Pioneers was created the Soviet
organization would be for children aged
9 to 14 their motto was summoned as
pioneer to fight for the cause of the
Communist Party of the Soviet Union
be prepared to which a young pioneer
would respond always ready or always
prepared
much like the Boy Scouts motto before
becoming old enough to join the Pioneers
Soviet children would be part of the
little October's
for ages 7 to 9 then after the Pioneers
they would graduate onto the Komsomol
for ages 14 to 28 with many of those
entering the Communist Party afterwards
while membership to these organizations
were optional in reality it was
obligatory and it was impossible to
pursue higher education if not a member
when they were ready to become a member
of the Pioneers a formal ceremony was
held at what was called a pioneers
palace these big buildings where
pioneers did their extracurricular
activities and they were often former
residences of the Tsar or nobility the
ceremony would see the aspiring pioneer
reciting the solemn promise then
receiving the distinctive red
neckerchief which was tied by an older
pioneer the ceremony was usually done on
either of two key dates in the Soviet
calendar April 22nd the birthday of
Lenin or May 19th
pioneers day
the Pioneers had many rules which
included to build up the Soviet Union
under communism and be prepared to
defend the motherland to uphold the
organization's honor be a good comrade
lead the little October ist's and
prepare to become a Komsomol member
during Stalin's regime he elevated the
status of the Young Pioneers as a part
of his cult of personality portraying
them as the models of a true socialist
future generation the youth represented
a blank canvas to indoctrinate the type
of socialism that he envisioned loyalty
to Stalin was taught and reporting on
anyone suspected of treason was
encouraged even if it was the Pioneers
parents during World War two Young
Pioneers supported the homefront those
that were near the invading German
forces fought on the front lines in
partisan units many were awarded medals
for their bravery in the defense of the
motherland thousands of pioneers would
die resisting the Nazis four of the
pioneers became heroes of the Soviet
Union posthumously the most distinctive
element of the Young Pioneers uniform
was the red neckerchief which showed
that they were pioneer status it
featured three corners which when untied
symbolized the unity between the
Pioneers
become small and adult communists a
white shirt with blue shorts or skirts
depending on the gender were worn and a
blue side cap known as a palooka was
worn on the head sometimes a red pittle
cup was worn for special occasions they
also wore a member pin with an image of
Lenin and an inscription reading always
ready for the sea service the uniform
featured sailor caps and blue and white
shirts at hand was that tovarisch
pioneer handbook provided for pioneers
with detailed drawings and descriptions
on the military such as uniforms and the
equipment of the Armed Forces through
the long history the pioneer
organization there were different goals
and objectives that were established by
the Komsomol and the Communist Party
many of the activities included games
and competitions between pioneers within
and among pioneer groups the purpose of
these activities were centered around
teaching the ideology of communism and
patriotism outdoor exercise
in adventure trips arts and crafts as
well as music and sports were all
popular activities pioneer spent their
summer vacations in camps where they met
pioneers from different cities and
villages or even republics one of the
most memorable parts of camp life was
the bonfire at the end of the camp turn
or on the pioneers day after new
pioneers were accepted pioneers would
attend class where they learned how to
draw and play musical instruments create
plain models published journals and
magazines and perform plays there were
also competitions challenging pioneers
to collect the most waste paper or scrap
metal many Soviet holidays were
celebrated with parades
they were comprised of veterans of World
War two factory workers teachers and
engineers laborers soldiers come smalls
and pioneers all marching through the
streets with music the purpose of the
parade's were to show how the Soviet
government cared about its people each
pioneer squad owned a flag drums and
horns which they used on official
meetings parades and events the
militaristic nature of the Young
Pioneers continued into the Cold War in
the 1960s pioneers participated in
military training and Czar Nitze meaning
heat lightning a type of Soviet war game
this would prepare the pioneer for
military service in defense of the
motherland teaching them bravery and
collectivism comradeship and discipline
from 1967 two years of military
instruction every week was compulsory
often these were lectures from World War
two veterans or reservists in the Red
Army in Pioneer palaces ex-servicemen
would teach the pioneers in military
skills including map reading
reconnaissance marksmanship and
first-aid during summer camp teams of
pioneers from the different palaces
competed in the massive czar Nitze war
games where they could use military
equipment in big simulated battles and
elating adult soldiers in the Red Army
for pioneers the goals and rules of the
game centered around attacking the
enemy's camp and taking their flags as
they became older they could move on to
using real armored vehicles and smoke
bombs when it came to grade five
practice was a new skill to learn as
pioneers age 12 to 13 were allowed to
use air rifles while the Komsomol age
group used small caliber rifles the
Pioneers would also learn to use gas
masks on how to give first aid to those
suffering from radiation exposure for
Lenin and the leaders that followed the
youth were important as they would be
the generation of loyal genuine
communists and such organizations as the
Young Pioneers proved to be an effective
indoctrination tool to achieve this goal
the Young Pioneers would continue all
the way till the end of the Soviet Union
disbanding in 1991 a big thank you to
world of warships for sponsoring this
episode
